skill.name: Playwright Browser Automation
skill.description: Complete browser automation with Playwright. Auto-detects dev servers, writes clean test scripts to /tmp. Test pages, fill forms, take screenshots, check responsive design, validate UX, test login flows, check links, automate any browser task. Use when user wants to test websites, automate browser interactions, validate web functionality, or perform any browser-based testing.
skill.summary: Complete browser automation with Playwright. Auto-detects dev servers, writes clean test scripts to ...
skill.author: Claude Assistant

security_audit.summary: Legitimate browser automation skill with appropriate capabilities. Uses external commands only for Playwright installation, filesystem access limited to skill directory and /tmp for test artifacts, script execution is core purpose.

content.value_statement: Automate any browser task including testing pages, filling forms, taking screenshots, validating responsive design, and testing login flows. Write clean test scripts that run reliably with visible browser for debugging.
actual_capabilities: Launch Chromium, Firefox, or WebKit browsers with configurable options
Auto-detect running dev servers on common ports for localhost testing
Write and execute Playwright scripts to test pages, forms, and workflows
Take screenshots at specific points or full page screenshots
Test responsive design across multiple viewport sizes
Test login flows with credential handling and session validation
limitations: Requires Playwright and browser installation via npm run setup
Scripts execute in visible browser by default unless headless is requested
No built-in API mocking or network request interception

use_cases.title: Test UI components
use_cases.description: Verify component rendering, responsive layouts, and user interactions across different viewports

use_cases.title: End-to-end testing

use_cases.title: Visual regression checks
use_cases.description: Take screenshots of pages to verify visual consistency and catch layout issues

prompt_templates.title: Quick screenshot
prompt_templates.prompt: Take a screenshot of http://localhost:3000 and save it to /tmp/homepage.png

prompt_templates.title: Test responsive
prompt_templates.prompt: Test how my homepage looks on desktop, tablet, and mobile viewports and take screenshots of each

prompt_templates.title: Form automation
prompt_templates.prompt: Fill out the contact form on /contact with test data and verify the submission succeeds

prompt_templates.title: Login flow
prompt_templates.prompt: Test the login flow by entering email test@example.com and password testpass123, then verify redirect to dashboard

output_examples.input: Test the login page on my dev server
output: Found dev server running on http://localhost:3001

best_practices: Always use TARGET_URL constant at top of scripts for easy configuration
Let the skill auto-detect dev servers before writing test code
Use waitForSelector and waitForURL instead of fixed timeouts for reliable tests
anti_patterns: Hardcoding URLs instead of using parameterized TARGET_URL
Using fixed sleep delays instead of explicit wait conditions
Writing test files to skill directory instead of /tmp for cleanup

faq.question: What browsers are supported?
faq.answer: Chromium, Firefox, and WebKit browsers are supported. Chromium is used by default.

faq.question: How do I run tests in headless mode?
faq.answer: Set HEADLESS=true environment variable or explicitly set headless:true in browser launch options.

faq.question: Can this skill test external websites?
faq.answer: Yes, provide any URL. For localhost, the skill auto-detects running dev servers first.

faq.question: Are my credentials safe?
faq.answer: Credentials are only used for the browser automation session and never stored or transmitted externally.

faq.question: Why are screenshots saved to /tmp?
faq.answer: The skill writes test artifacts to /tmp for automatic cleanup and to avoid cluttering your project.

faq.question: How is this different from Cypress or Selenium?
faq.answer: Playwright supports multiple browsers, better async handling, and is designed for modern web testing needs.
